fields.description:
my command is *test-app* but in the log I can see that Bamboo calls:

bq. running command line: /import/tools/grails/grails-1.3.4/bin/grails *test-app test-app*

The result is that tests are not performed.
fields.summary: Grails builder duplicates command

fields.description:
The message currently reads: 

"8 agents are capable of building this Job. However, those agents are currently offline or disabled. This Job is capable of building in the Elastic Cloud on 8 images." 

This is way to long for this section and distracts with the red color from the actual task at hand. We should shorten this to:

"8 agents and 8 images have the _capabilities_ to run this job"

Link capabilities to the requirements tab. The numbers are for agents (whether online or offline) people can click through to the requirements tab where they can see the more detailed message

We should also align the text on the right, see screenshot.
fields.summary: Simplify capability message on Tasks

fields.description:
Please use the following text instead of the existing, too wordy one. 

"A Task is a piece of work that is being executed as part of the Build. The execution of a script, a shell command, an Ant Task or a Maven goal are only few examples of Tasks. Learn more about tasks."
fields.summary: Change Task configuration description

fields.description:
h3. Scenario

A stage has multiple jobs. As soon as a job fails the {{state}} should be updated to reflect the build outcome (Failed) even though the build itself hasn't failed yet.

Example REST resource for a running build:

https://bamboo.example.com/rest/api/latest/result/CONFFUNC-MAIN/9145

{code}
<result id="194281685" number="9145" lifeCycleState="InProgress" state="Unknown" key="CONFFUNC-MAIN-9145" expand="changes,metadata,artifacts,comments,labels,jiraIssues,stages">
{code}

If one of the jobs in the stage fails, the whole build will fail but the {{state}} is still "Unknown".

h3. Use case

We have a custom wallboard that we could update to reflect the build outcome as soon as one of the jobs fails. This would shorten the feedback loop.
fields.summary: Update the "state" attribute of the REST result resource as soon as the build outcome is known

fields.description:
When on the Bamboo website on a particular build user can select the "Changes" tab. This tab will then list all the changes with the author followed by individual entries commited by him/her.

It can be rather difficult to browse the changes when there is a lot of them. Therefore I propose a collapse/expand functionality for this tab. By default all changes can be collapsed with user being able to expand manually individual change (a + button on the left side of a change could do this when clicked). There could also be an "Expand All"/"Collapse All" button on the page that would allow the user to expand all the changes and then collapse them (after they were expanded).
fields.summary: Changes tab and expand/collapse functionality.

fields.description: On slow connections/servers the lag is noticeable, and the dialog just shows blank for a while until the content is fetched.
fields.summary: New dialog forms should have a loading spinner while content is waiting to load

fields.description: We store build errors against a plan/job, if multiple occurances of the error happen, we only store the number of occurances plus the build that it last occurred in.  This means that the error is only displayed on the latest build result, and if you are looking at an earlier build result there is no context or indication as to what went wrong.
fields.summary: Errors that occur for multiple builds should show on all build results

fields.description: Since we also support dependency management for Maven 3, this tab should be called "Maven"
fields.summary: Rename "Maven 2" tab to "Maven"

fields.description: BAM-8070 caused a regression in deadlock fix done for BAM-6746 . More information in https://studio.atlassian.com/source/cru/CR-JST-520 .
fields.summary: Deadlock in agent classloader

fields.description: Processing of a single request is costly (0.5 - 2 seconds wallclock) and does not increase dramatically with the request size. Web actions and instance startup threads should use a common data source so that we don't bomb AWS with requests (the current worst case scenario - a misconfigured Bamboo or no auctionable AWS resources - is a request every second).
fields.summary: 20% - AWS Spot instance request status should not be polled separately by each thread

fields.description:
How to reproduce:
1) Grab 'large-repo' from [BSP-4370|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-4370].
2) Set up Git plan using that repo, run it once.
3) Run it again.
3a) In logs there should be no messages alike "failed to checkout, trying to recover".
3b) And in bamboo logs there shouldn't be
{noformat}

fields.description: It would be cool if GitHub/Bitbucket plans could have set up by default a special WebRepositoryViewer(s), which would link directly to the proper changesets/diffs seen on github.com or bitbucket.org sites.
fields.summary: GitHub/Bitbucket source control could have own web repository

fields.description:
See [BSP-4425|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-4425] for the details.

{quote}
OK I think I found the issue. In a normal windows environment, we run MSYSGit using Putty for its SSH and TortoiseGit and we also install Cygwin without git or ssh. When I uninstalled all of them and just installed MSYSGit, everything started to work. *When JGit tried to open an SSH session, it was being forwarded to Putty's implementation of ssh and JGit does not seem to play well with this ssh implementation*. By only installing MSYSGit, only the included version of ssh is now installed and everything seems to be working.
{quote}

In such scenario user will encounter (in the build logs, so I don't know how could he even accept the fingerprint):
{code}
git@dev:media: The server's host key is not cached in the registry. You
 have no guarantee that the server is the computer you
 think it is.
 The server's rsa2 key fingerprint is:
 ssh-rsa 1024 76:63:33:1c:f3:d7:41:1c:fc:18:15:e1:0b:34:f9:12
 Connection abandoned.
{code}
...and also whole Git Repository will become useless, as it won't be able to fetch remote git repository.

Dunno what we should do with this issue:
* try to fix jGit/Git Plugin, so it works nicely with Putty SSH? (AFAIK Mercurial Repository doesn't work with Putty SSH, but on the other hand Hg doesn't come with windows installer allowing to choose "install with putty for the SSH"...)
* try to discover if user have such environment and if so - throw him a meaningful error message
* ask [Eric Berry|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-4425] what he would expect from Git Plugin in such scenario
* update documentation with a 'known issues'
* do nothing
* something else
fields.summary: Git Repository on Windows should (should?) work with Putty SSH

fields.description:
In 3.0 the artifacts got removed from the buildDefinition into their own table.
In several upgrade tasks we get that buildDefinition out of the database, then convert to objects, then reconvert back into xml.  In this conversion process the artifacts are not saved (because the BD converter doesn't convert them anymore).

Upgrade Tasks That Open then re-save the build Cofiguration
UT1702 - web repositories
UT2025 - build/chain conversion
UT2032 - change of dep provider id to be plan key
UT2033 - migration of maven2 dependency config out of builder config into custom config
UT2204 - artifact conversion
UT2405 - task conversion

Option 1: fix all the above upgrade tasks so they deal directly with the xml, rather than converting to an object
Option 2: put the artifacts conversion code back into the BuildDefinition Converter
Option 3: Fix Artifacts upgrade task to be priority upgrade task, and make it read the xml directly from the db.  (it can not load the plan because we might have null columns etc.)

Chai decided option 3 is the way to go.  We also need to check the rest of our upgrade tasks to make sure there are not other significant places
fields.summary: Artifacts being removed when upgrading from 2.6 to 3.0

fields.description:
While checking out: https://github.com/krosenvold/bgit.git
Checkout to revision 67fc88bf41aa2ddea0e50159868764c82bed5bad has failed due to Missing object 3a450411d6868221ae290bc0c17695de2990d5d8. Note this might happen if the repository contains submodules, as Bamboo does not currently support git submodules.

Is it a bug? How can I find out if the repo contains submodules?
fields.summary: Bamboo fails to check out git code due to 'Missing object' but command line git clones the repo just fine

fields.description:
Feature BAM-8073 will allow Bamboo users to pass/replace parameters in a Plan by using the UI.

However, one of the possible use cases will be to pass passwords that can be used during the build or tests.

Would be good, for security reasons, to be able to define what parameters not to log (in the UI or in the Log files) so that the passwords can be hidden.
fields.summary: Allow Admins to define what parameters will not be logged

fields.description:
When using JBAM in JIRA, Bamboo redirects users who are not authenticated on the Bamboo server to the login screen when they click any link pertaining to builds, plans, users, etc. But not when they click on artifact links.

See bug filed in JBAM project for more information: https://studio.plugins.atlassian.com/browse/JBAM-8

fields.description:
There are a few ways of implementing this;
# Clean up the temp directory during start-up
# Have an expiry mechanism (cron job similar to build expiry)
# Bamboo should automatically clean up itself after each build

Note: If you are planning to delete this directory, it is important to cleanup when Bamboo server is not running (as there might be builds using the files in this directory).
fields.summary: Mechanism to clean up Bamboo-Home/temp directory.
